newsitem.title: GERMANY: German shares end day with losses on profit-taking.
newsitem.headline: German shares end day with losses on profit-taking.

text.p: German shares ended bourse trade on Monday lower, hurt by profit taking after the DAX index on Friday surged to a new all-time high on buying tied to the expiry of DAX futures and options and stock options.
The 30-share DAX ended the session down 33.55 points at 3,754.72 points and near the session low of 3,751.23 points.
The IBIS DAX, which reflects all-day computer trade, later ended down 39.75 points, or 1.05 percent, at 3,748.79 points.

"Everything seems to be going against the DAX right now," said one Frankfurt trader. "Everyone had their mind on the expiry last Friday and it's been very quiet today. There's no reason for the rally to continue right now."
A slightly weaker dollar and German debt market losses also capped enthusiasm for buying as traders predicted further range trade with a downside bias.
The DAX index should find support at 3,750 points on any more selling, with further support evident at 3,740 points.
"We had a big expiry on Friday and the market is trying to find its feet," said another Frankfurt share trader.
But some traders said the dollar's ongoing stability above 1.70 marks was supportive and would underpin export-sensitive shares, particularly in the chemical and carmaker industries.
Among specific shares, television network ProSieben was in the spotlight as its shares surged in grey market dealings.
ProSieben, the first television network in Germany to go public, set its bookbuilding price range for an initial offering of preference shares at 66 to 72 marks per share.
Traders said grey market bids for the shares were quickly indicated at 100 marks before slipping to about 95 marks.

Telephone group Deutsche Telekom ended up 50 pfennigs at 43.15 marks after it denied a report that it planned to dismiss board member Herbert May after talks over allowing other telecoms firms access to Deutsche's network broke down.
May is responsible for business clients at Telekom.
One German brokerage house said pharmaceuticals group Bayer AG, industrial group Daimler-Benz AG and electronics group Siemens AG were in favour due to technical factors.
Siemens rose 1.55 marks to 103.20 marks in bourse trade but Bayer ended down 1.21 marks at 68.45 marks and Daimler was down 60 pfennigs at 136.40 marks.
